reading_comprehension_problems.passage:
Manufacturers masterfully sow seeds of doubt about the adequacy of our current devices.
Suddenly, the phone that was your lifeline a year ago is now a museum piece, unable to keep pace with your digital demands.
And thus, the itch to upgrade begins, often before there's a genuine need.
This cycle isn't just confined to our digital companions.
It spills over into almost every aspect of consumer electronics, from the self-driving car to the smart fridge.
Every product seems to be on an unstoppable march towards the next version, the next generation that promises to revolutionize your life.
What's fascinating, or perhaps disturbing, is the utter efficacy of this cycle in shaping our desires.
It's not so much that we want the newest device; we're led to believe we need it.
The distinction between want and need blurs, shifting our financial priorities in favor of staying current with trends.
For all the logical arguments against this ceaseless upgrading, the temptation remains compelling.
reading_comprehension_problems.question: 다음 글의 목적으로 가장 적절한 것은?

options.text: to advertise the latest consumer electronics
to provide tips for saving money on technology
to critique the marketing strategies that fuel the upgrade cycle
to praise manufacturers for their constant innovation
to predict the future of smart home devices

answer.explanation: 이 글은 제조사들이 어떻게 '의심의 씨앗을 교묘하게 심어' 소비자들이 실제 필요가 없어도 계속해서 새 제품으로 업그레이드하도록 유도하는지를 설명합니다. 이 과정의 효과를 '불안하게 하는(disturbing)'이라고 표현하며, 소비 심리를 조장하는 마케팅 전략에 대한 비판적인 시각을 드러내는 것이 글의 주된 목적입니다.

reading_comprehension_problems.passage:
Manufacturers masterfully sow seeds of doubt about the adequacy of our current devices.
Suddenly, the phone that was your lifeline a year ago is now a museum piece, unable to keep pace with your digital demands.
And thus, the itch to upgrade begins, often before there's a genuine need.
This cycle isn't just confined to our digital companions.
It spills over into almost every aspect of consumer electronics, from the self-driving car to the smart fridge.
Every product seems to be on an unstoppable march towards the next version, the next generation that promises to revolutionize your life.
What's fascinating, or perhaps disturbing, is the utter efficacy of this cycle in shaping our desires.
It's not so much that we want the newest device; we're led to believe we need it.
The distinction between want and need blurs, shifting our financial priorities in favor of staying current with trends.
For all the logical arguments against this ceaseless upgrading, the temptation remains compelling.
reading_comprehension_problems.question: 다음 글의 제목으로 가장 적절한 것은?

options.text: The Evolution of the Smart Phone
The Upgrade Itch: A Manufactured Need
Smart Homes: A Revolution in Living
Financial Planning in the Digital Age

answer.explanation: 이 글은 소비자들이 '업그레이드하고 싶은 갈망(the itch to upgrade)'을 느끼는 이유가 제조사들이 '필요(need)'를 '만들어내기(manufactured)' 때문이라고 분석합니다. 즉, 진정한 필요보다는 인위적으로 조성된 욕구에 의해 업그레이드 주기가 돌아간다는 핵심 내용을 '업그레이드 갈망: 만들어진 필요'라는 제목이 가장 잘 요약하고 있습니다.

reading_comprehension_problems.passage:
Manufacturers masterfully sow seeds of doubt about the adequacy of our current devices.
Suddenly, the phone that was your lifeline a year ago is now a museum piece, unable to keep pace with your digital demands.
And thus, the itch to upgrade begins, often before there's a genuine need.
This cycle isn't just confined to our digital companions.
It spills over into almost every aspect of consumer electronics, from the self-driving car to the smart fridge.
Every product seems to be on an unstoppable march towards the next version, the next generation that promises to revolutionize your life.
What's fascinating, or perhaps disturbing, is the utter efficacy of this cycle in shaping our desires.
It's not so much that we want the newest device; we're led to believe we need it.
The distinction between want and need blurs, shifting our financial priorities in favor of staying current with trends.
For all the logical arguments against this ceaseless upgrading, the temptation remains compelling.
reading_comprehension_problems.question: 다음 글의 요지로 가장 적절한 것은?

options.text: Technological advancement in electronics has significantly improved the overall quality of our modern lives.
Manufacturers deliberately create a sense of dissatisfaction to drive a continuous cycle of consumer upgrades.
It is financially irresponsible for consumers to purchase new devices before they actually need them.
The distinction between wanting something and needing something is very clear to most consumers.
The rapid pace of innovation means that older devices quickly become completely useless and obsolete.

answer.explanation: 글의 핵심 주장은 제조사들이 현재 기기의 '적절성(adequacy)'에 대해 '의심의 씨앗을 심어' 소비자들이 불만족을 느끼게 하고, 이를 통해 지속적인 업그레이드 주기를 유도한다는 것입니다. 따라서 '제조사들은 소비자 업그레이드의 지속적인 순환을 유도하기 위해 의도적으로 불만족감을 조성한다'는 ②번 선택지가 글의 요지를 가장 정확하게 나타냅니다.

reading_comprehension_problems.passage:
Manufacturers masterfully sow seeds of doubt about the adequacy of our current devices.
Suddenly, the phone that was your lifeline a year ago is now a museum piece, unable to keep pace with your digital demands.
And thus, the itch to upgrade begins, often before there's a genuine need.
( ① ) This cycle isn't just confined to our digital companions.
( ② ) Every product seems to be on an unstoppable march towards the next version, the next generation that promises to revolutionize your life.
( ③ ) What's fascinating, or perhaps disturbing, is the utter efficacy of this cycle in shaping our desires.
( ④ ) It's not so much that we want the newest device; we're led to believe we need it.
( ⑤ ) The distinction between want and need blurs, shifting our financial priorities in favor of staying current with trends.
reading_comprehension_problems.question:
글의 흐름으로 보아, 주어진 문장이 들어가기에 가장 적절한 곳은?

**It spills over into almost every aspect of consumer electronics, from the self-driving car to the smart fridge.**

answer.explanation: ②번 앞 문장은 '이러한 주기는 단지 우리의 디지털 동반자(휴대폰 등)에만 국한되지 않는다'고 말하며 논의의 범위를 확장할 것을 암시합니다. 주어진 문장은 '그것은 거의 모든 소비자 가전제품으로 번져나간다'고 말하며 구체적인 예시(자율주행차, 스마트 냉장고)를 들어 이 확장을 설명합니다. 뒤따르는 문장은 '모든 제품이...'라며 이 확장된 범위를 일반화하므로, 주어진 문장은 이 두 문장 사이에 위치하여 논리를 매끄럽게 연결하는 역할을 합니다.

reading_comprehension_problems.passage: Manufacturers masterfully sow seeds of doubt about the adequacy of our current devices. Suddenly, the phone that was your lifeline a year ago is now a museum piece, unable to keep pace with your digital demands.

question_blocks.A: What's fascinating, or perhaps disturbing, is the utter efficacy of this cycle in shaping our desires. It's not so much that we want the newest device; we're led to believe we need it.
question_blocks.B: And thus, the itch to upgrade begins, often before there's a genuine need. This cycle isn't just confined to our digital companions; it spills over into almost every aspect of consumer electronics.
question_blocks.C: The distinction between want and need blurs, shifting our financial priorities in favor of staying current with trends. For all the logical arguments against this ceaseless upgrading, the temptation remains compelling.

reading_comprehension_problems.question: 주어진 글 다음에 이어질 글의 순서로 가장 적절한 것은?

answer.explanation: 주어진 글은 제조사들이 어떻게 소비자의 기기를 낡아 보이게 만드는지 설명합니다. (B)는 그 결과로 '업그레이드하고 싶은 갈망이 시작'되고, 이 현상이 모든 가전제품으로 확장됨을 보여줍니다. (A)는 이 주기의 심리적 효과를 분석하며, 소비자들이 단순히 '원하는 것'을 넘어 '필요하다'고 믿게 되는 과정을 설명합니다. (C)는 (A)에서 언급된 '필요와 욕구의 구분이 흐려지는' 현상의 결과(재정적 우선순위 변화)를 설명하고, 이 유혹이 강력하다는 결론으로 마무리합니다. 따라서 현상 설명(B) → 심리 분석(A) → 결과 및 결론(C)의 순서가 가장 자연스럽습니다.

reading_comprehension_problems.passage:
Manufacturers masterfully sow seeds of doubt about the adequacy of our current devices.
Suddenly, the phone that was your lifeline a year ago is now a museum piece, unable to keep pace with your digital demands.
And thus, the itch to upgrade begins, often before there's a genuine need.
This cycle isn't just confined to our digital companions.
It spills over into almost every aspect of consumer electronics, from the self-driving car to the smart fridge.
Every product seems to be on an unstoppable march towards the next version, the next generation that promises to revolutionize your life.
What's fascinating, or perhaps disturbing, is the utter efficacy of this cycle in __________________________.
It's not so much that we want the newest device; we're led to believe we need it.
The distinction between want and need blurs, shifting our financial priorities in favor of staying current with trends.
For all the logical arguments against this ceaseless upgrading, the temptation remains compelling.
reading_comprehension_problems.question: 다음 글의 빈칸에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은?

answer.explanation: 빈칸은 업그레이드 주기의 효과에 대해 설명하는 부분입니다. 바로 다음 문장에서 '우리가 최신 기기를 원하는 것이 아니라, 그것이 필요하다고 믿게 된다'고 설명하며, 그 다음 문장에서는 '원함과 필요의 구분이 흐려진다'고 말합니다. 이 모든 내용은 이 주기가 우리의 '욕구를 형성하는' 데 얼마나 효과적인지를 보여주는 구체적인 예시입니다. 따라서 빈칸에는 'shaping our desires'가 들어가는 것이 가장 적절합니다.

reading_comprehension_problems.passage:
Manufacturers masterfully sow seeds of doubt about the ① [adequacy] of our current devices.
Suddenly, the phone that was your lifeline a year ago is now a museum piece, unable to keep pace with your digital demands.
And thus, the itch to upgrade begins, often before there's a ② [genuine] need.
This cycle isn't just confined to our digital companions.
It spills over into almost every aspect of consumer electronics, from the self-driving car to the smart fridge.
Every product seems to be on an ③ [unstoppable] march towards the next version, the next generation that promises to revolutionize your life.
What's fascinating, or perhaps disturbing, is the utter efficacy of this cycle in shaping our desires.
It's not so much that we want the newest device; we're led to believe we need it.
The distinction between want and need ④ [blurs], shifting our financial priorities in favor of staying current with trends.
For all the logical arguments against this ceaseless upgrading, the temptation remains ⑤ [minimal].
reading_comprehension_problems.question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?

answer.explanation: 글의 마지막 문장은 끊임없는 업그레이드에 반대하는 논리적인 주장들이 있음에도 불구하고, 그 유혹은 여전히 강력하게 남아있다는 내용입니다. 따라서 '최소한의(minimal)'이라는 단어는 문맥에 맞지 않으며, '강력한(compelling)'과 같은 단어가 와야 합니다.

reading_comprehension_problems.passage:
Manufacturers masterfully sow seeds of doubt about the (A) [adequacy] of our current devices.
Suddenly, the phone that was your lifeline a year ago is now a museum piece, unable to keep pace with your digital demands.
And thus, the itch to upgrade begins, often before there's a (B) [genuine] need.
This cycle isn't just confined to our digital companions.
It spills over into almost every aspect of consumer electronics, from the self-driving car to the smart fridge.
Every product seems to be on an unstoppable march towards the next version, the next generation that promises to (C) [revolutionize] your life.
What's fascinating, or perhaps disturbing, is the utter (D) [efficacy] of this cycle in shaping our desires.
The distinction between want and need blurs, shifting our financial priorities in favor of staying current with trends.
For all the logical arguments against this (E) [ceaseless] upgrading, the temptation remains compelling.
reading_comprehension_problems.question: 밑줄 친 (A)~(E)에 대한 영영 풀이가 적절하지 않은 것은?

options.text: (A) adequacy: the state of being satisfactory or acceptable in quality
(B) genuine: truly what something is said to be; authentic
(C) revolutionize: to change something in a minor and insignificant way
(D) efficacy: the ability to produce a desired or intended result

answer.explanation: (C) 'revolutionize'는 '완전히 새롭게 바꾸다, 혁신을 일으키다'라는 의미로, 근본적이고 중대한 변화를 뜻합니다. 제시된 영영 풀이인 '사소하고 중요하지 않은 방식으로 무언가를 바꾸다'는 그 의미와 정반대입니다.

reading_comprehension_problems.passage:
Manufacturers masterfully sow seeds of doubt about the (A) [adequacy / superiority] of our current devices.
Suddenly, the phone that was your lifeline a year ago is now a museum piece, unable to keep pace with your digital demands.
And thus, the itch to upgrade begins, often before there's a genuine need.
This cycle isn't just (B) [confined / expanded] to our digital companions.
It spills over into almost every aspect of consumer electronics.
What's fascinating, or perhaps disturbing, is the utter efficacy of this cycle in shaping our desires.
It's not so much that we want the newest device; we're led to believe we need it.
The distinction between want and need (C) [blurs / sharpens], shifting our financial priorities in favor of staying current with trends.
reading_comprehension_problems.question: (A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장 적절한 것은?

answer.explanation: (A) 제조사들은 우리 기기가 충분히 좋은지, 즉 '적절성(adequacy)'에 대해 의심을 심습니다. (B) 이 주기는 휴대폰에만 '국한되지(confined)' 않습니다. (C) 이 과정은 필요와 욕구 사이의 구분을 '흐리게 만듭니다(blurs)'.

reading_comprehension_problems.passage:
Manufacturers masterfully sow seeds of doubt about the adequacy of our current devices.
Suddenly, the phone that was your lifeline a year ago is now a museum piece, unable to keep pace with your digital demands.
And thus, the itch to upgrade begins, often before there's a genuine need.
This cycle isn't just confined to our digital companions.
It spills over into almost every aspect of consumer electronics, from the self-driving car to the smart fridge.
Every product seems to be on an unstoppable march towards the next version, the next generation that promises to revolutionize your life.
What's fascinating, or perhaps disturbing, is the utter efficacy of this cycle in shaping our desires.
It's not so much that we want the newest device; we're led to believe we need it.
The distinction between want and need blurs, shifting our financial priorities in favor of staying current with trends.
For all the logical arguments against this ceaseless upgrading, the temptation remains compelling.
reading_comprehension_problems.question: 다음 글의 내용과 일치하지 않는 것은?

options.text: 제조사들은 소비자가 현재 기기에 불만을 느끼도록 유도한다.
업그레이드 욕구는 실제 필요가 생기기 전에 시작되기도 한다.
업그레이드 주기는 주로 휴대폰과 같은 디지털 기기에만 한정된다.
소비자들은 최신 기기를 원하는 것을 넘어 필요하다고 믿게 된다.
끊임없는 업그레이드에 대한 유혹은 상당히 강력하다.

answer.explanation: 본문은 'This cycle isn't just confined to our digital companions. It spills over into almost every aspect of consumer electronics...'라고 명시하며, 이 업그레이드 주기가 디지털 기기에만 국한되지 않고 거의 모든 소비자 가전제품으로 확산된다고 설명합니다. 따라서 ③번은 글의 내용과 일치하지 않습니다.

reading_comprehension_problems.passage:
Manufacturers masterfully sow seeds of doubt about the adequacy of our current devices.
Suddenly, the phone that was your lifeline a year ago is now a museum piece, ① [unable / is unable] to keep pace with your digital demands.
What's fascinating, or perhaps disturbing, ② [is / are] the utter efficacy of this cycle in shaping our desires.
It's not so much that we want the newest device; we're led to believe we need it.
The distinction between want and need blurs, shifting our financial priorities in favor of staying current with trends.
For all the logical arguments against this ceaseless upgrading, the temptation remains ③ [compelling / compellingly].
reading_comprehension_problems.question: 다음 글의 각 네모 안에서 어법에 맞는 표현으로 가장 적절한 것을 각각 고르시오.

answer.explanation: 쉼표 뒤의 'unable to keep pace...'는 앞의 명사구 'a museum piece'를 부가적으로 설명하는 형용사구입니다. 여기에 동사 'is'가 들어가면 문장 구조가 어색해집니다. 주절의 동사는 이미 'is'가 있으므로, 또 다른 동사가 접속사 없이 올 수 없습니다.
문장의 주어는 'What's fascinating, or perhaps disturbing'이라는 명사절입니다. 명사절 주어는 단수 취급하므로 단수 동사 'is'가 와야 합니다.
동사 'remains'는 '~인 채로 남아있다'는 의미의 2형식 동사로, 주격 보어를 필요로 합니다. 보어 자리에는 형용사가 와야 하므로 'compelling'이 적절합니다. 부사인 'compellingly'는 올 수 없습니다.
